intro: Chromolaena vindex, commonly known as Hawaiian tridax, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of the Americas. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are arranged in clusters, followed by fluffy, white seeds that are dispersed by wind. It is often considered an invasive species in parts of the Pacific Islands due to its rapid growth and ability to outcompete native vegetation. Its botanical features make it both ecologically significant and a challenge for land management.
